content: Luxembourg city - Luxembourg's independent history dates back to 963
- Treaty of London gives the western part of the country to the recently-created state of Belgium - giving Luxembourg its modern-day borders.

- Luxembourg crisis nearly sees war between France and Prussia as neither is willing concede influence in Luxembourg to its rival. The crisis is solved by an agreement on Luxembourg's independence and neutrality at the Second Treaty of London in 1867.
- Outbreak of World War One. Luxembourg is occupied by Germany until 1918.
- Luxembourg joins the League of Nations.
- Luxembourg enters economic union with Belgium. The use of the Belgian currency in Luxembourg is permitted.
- Luxembourg is again occupied by Germany. The occupation lasts for most of World War Two, until 1944.
- Luxembourg abandons its neutrality and forms an economic union with Belgium and the Netherlands - the Benelux countries.
- Luxembourg joins Nato.
- Luxembourg becomes founder member of the European Economic Community (now the European Union) which comes into effect in January 1958.
- Grand Duchess Charlotte abdicates in favour of her son, who becomes Grand Duke Jean.
- The Christian Social party fails to win elections and is out of government for the first time since the end of World War One. New government coalition between the Democrats and the Socialists.
- Christian Social party regains power. Luxembourg enters period of economic recession.
- Jacques Santer becomes prime minister. He remains in power until 1995.
- Luxembourg adopts the Maastricht Treaty creating the European Union.
- Jean-Claude Juncker becomes prime minister after Jacques Santer is appointed president of the European Commission.
- Jean-Claude Juncker re-elected as prime minister
- Crown Prince Henri becomes Grand Duke of Luxembourg on the abdication of his father, Jean.
January - Euro introduced as national currency.
June - Jean-Claude Juncker again invited to form government after his party wins general election, in coalition with the Socialists.
July - Voters back a proposed EU constitution, rejected earlier in the year by French and Dutch voters.
December - Parliament approves reform restricting the monarch to a purely ceremonial role after Grand Duke Henri's threat to block a bill legalising euthanasia sparks a constitutional crisis.
April - G20 adds Luxembourg to "grey list" of countries with questionable banking arrangements.

July - Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) commends Luxembourg for improving financial transparency with agreements on the exchange of tax information with a dozen countries.
October - Heir-apparent Prince Guillaume marries.
July - The Socialists quit the government over a phone-tapping scandal. PM Jean-Claude Juncker resigns, paving the way for early elections.
October - Mr Juncker's centre-right Christian Social Party emerges as the largest party at elections, but fails to form a coalition.
December - Xavier Bettel of the Democratic Party forms a centre-left coalition with the Socialists and Greens on a programme of spending cuts, tax rises and social liberalisation.
June - Luxembourg's parliament votes to legalise same-sex marriage.
November - The so-called LuxLeaks scandal casts light on how Luxembourg helped hundreds of multi-national companies - Apple, Ikea, and Pepsi among them - save billions of dollars in tax payments.
March - OECD urges Luxembourg to reduce economic dependence on financial services to multinational businesses to avoid a G20-led crackdown on international tax avoidance.
June - A referendum proposal to allow foreigners to vote in national elections is rejected by a large margin.

June - In a continuation of the so-called LuxLeaks scandal, two former employees of accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers are given suspended prison sentences for leaking confidential documents revealing corporate tax deals.
